Alternate Site Testing (AST) is blood glucose self-monitoring using a blood sample collected from somewhere other than the ﬁngertips; the BG5 allows testing on the palm, forearm, upper arm, calf, or thigh with equivalent results to fingertip testing.

AST is appropriate in a pre-meal or fasting state (two hours or more after the last meal); two hours or more after taking insulin; two hours or more after exercising; only during steady–state times when glucose levels are not changing rapidly.
Avoid AST if you think your blood glucose is low; you believe you may be hypoglycemic; you are testing for hyperglycemia; your routine glucose results fluctuate often; you are pregnant
No; AST readings should not be used to calibrate CGMs or to calculate insulin doses
Pain is felt less acutely at alternate sites because they have fewer nerve endings than fingertips.

The BG5 measures glucose by detecting the electrical current generated when glucose in the blood reacts with the reagent on a test strip; the strength of the current corresponds to the blood glucose level.
The meter and lancing device are for single-patient use and should not be shared.

Perform a Control Solution test to ensure meter is working properly; if possible, fast for at least eight hours before the comparison test; take your Wireless Smart Glucose Meter with you to the lab.

Severe dehydration and excessive water loss may cause results that are lower than actual values; if you believe you are suffering from severe dehydration, consult a healthcare professional immediately; if your blood glucose results are lower or higher than usual and you do not have symptoms of illness, first repeat the test; if you have symptoms or continue to get unusual results, follow your healthcare professional's advice; if you experience symptoms inconsistent with your test results and have followed all instructions, contact your healthcare professional.
